etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Thomas Morton. From verbal + -ity

definitions: The quality or fact of being (merely) verbal; speech or writing, especially when long-winded, verbose, or lacking in meaning, substance, value, a basis in reality, etc.; verbalism.
In plural. Verbal expressions or phrases, especially when long-winded, verbose, or lacking in meaning, substance, value, a basis in reality, etc.
The quality or fact of being, deriving from, or functioning as a verb.

notes.text: Apparently only attested in dictionaries before the mid 19th century.
